inn1.comm: loping in over the wicket, pitched up around off stump and Amla quietly taps down on it
full of a length and signs of some swing for Toppers, defended
insistent appeal from Topley, as he brings the ball back into Amla's front pad, he was aiming a drive down the ground and is saved by a thick inside edge
gets across on off stump to defend
pushed across the right-hander, stays a touch low as Amla leaves, Buttler takes at ankle height
too straight from Toply, straightening down the leg side and Amla scraffs four with a flick past short fine leg. Runs on the board
over the wicket, good length outside off, de Kock watches his first ball through
some away swing for Willey, trying to tempt de Kock outside off, left alone
this time de Kock does go after it, there's a sound as the ball passes the bat, big drive from de Kock - and has he nicked it? England think so but the umpire is unmoved. Bat on the ground
good ball from Willey, 129kph and nibbling back after threatening to swing away, beaten on the inside
length around off stump, gets across and chops into the ground
slightly back of a length, de Kock tucks it off his hips but straight to short fine leg - so Willey opens with a pristine maiden
length ball on the stumps, gets across to defend

gottim, off stump rattled! Amla is bowled off his pads, he's not enjoyed this angle of attack and Topley gets one through his defences, it shaped back but Amla played the wrong line, past the outside edge and flicking the back leg - would have been plumb lbw if the ball hadn't deflected on to off stump. It was actually a cracking ball, looked to be swinging and then nipped away
gets across to defend a shorter delivery on off
pitched up on the stumps, dug out towards mid-on
good length around off, steered towards backward point
128kph, not much more than brisk, leg-stump line and du Plessis defends
presses forward to defend on off
that's a lovely back from Willey, swings it away searchingly, past the bat as de Kock pushes out
in the channel, tight lines from Willey, this is left alone
pitched up and met on the front foot, punched back to the bowler who fields
fullish length, 134kph outside off, pushed away off the outer half of the bat
full on the stumps, tries to drive through mid-on but doesn't really connect and it dribbles to the fielder - second maiden in a row for Willey. Top start
pitched up and shaping in, du Plessis works it away to midwicket for one
full around off stump, swinging enough to take the leading edge as de Kock closes the face... but it loops over Topley and short of mid-off
good length and enticing the push outside off, takes the edge again but this one bounces short of second slip... Testing times for Quinny
ah, that'll do, a half-volley in the channel and de Kock is on de board, slapping a drive through the covers for four
sliding on to the pads, clipped through square leg to the man on the fence
angled across, lets this one fly through
back of a length, de Kock waits for it in the crease and swats a pull out to deep square leg... Six off his last three balls now, he's motoring
good length around off stump, du Plessis defends on the back foot
tight lines, chopped down into the ground
pitched up around 129kph on off stump, comes forward and strokes it to mid-off
slightly full, tighter than Scrooge McDuck's wallet, du Plessis shows it due deference coming forwards
gets on to the front foot and this time picks a gap at extra cover for one
du Plessis remembers that his feet were made for walking, advances on Topley and thick edges a drive down to third man
length ball, 130kph around off stump, poked away
sticking to his plans, no room for de Kock to swing those dinky forearms
gets another leading edge, Topley straightens the ball from back of a length as de Kock fends at it, pops into the covers
hoicked in the air, out towards deep square leg, Alex Hales thinks he's in the game... but it bounces well short and then zips past him as he tumbles forwards
on the pads and glances for another boundary, that'll help the run rate. No fine leg and du Plessis just helps it on its way
slightly back of a length outside off, bunted into the ground
speared down the leg side as de Kock walks across
pitched up and clumped through the covers, not quite timed and Morgan chases it down
133kph on off stump, dances across and tries to drive on the up, trundles back to the bowler
length outside off, not enough width for de Kock's cut and he bottom-edges into the turf
back of a length and swishes through midwicket off the back foot
shortish again, nudged off the body through backward square for one more - these are superb opening figures from Willey, a rare opportunity to economise in these ODI boom times
good length outside off, some gentle shape for the right-armer, du Plessis has time to watch it through
straighter line, worked into the leg side and they scramble through for one
shot! Quinny is up on tippy toe to punch down the ground, the ball was back of a length and sweetly timed whence it came
pushed across the lefty, tapped down
good pace, 143kph but down the leg side
touch short outside off, chopped towards point

lovely timing again from de Kock, this time off his legs, forced past midwicket and Adil Rashid can't quite cut it off from deep square leg, he got down to grab it but in tumbling over his head, I think, brushed the boundary marker before he released the ball
plugging away with the diligence of a seasoned auditor, blocked on off stump
lovely stuff from du Plessis to open things up, skipping down the pitch, gives himself room to hit through the line and crunches a drive fine of mid-off
fired in full, drops the bat on it
short ball, no pace in the surface and clattered for six over deep midwicket! Seized on it like a bear trap snapping shut, went off the middle like shot
full around off stump, du Plessis drives powerfully but finds mid-off on the edge of the ring this time
another boundary, creamed through the covers! De Kock joins in the fun, rasping a drive to the fence to bring up South Africa's 50
gets across and opens the face, runs one to third man
shortish, pushed away into the covers
back of a length, attempts to pull but gets a bottom edge down towards his boots

on the stumps, straightening a touch and de Kock misses playing across the line... Dharmasena gives it! The batsman is going to review and only the matter of whether it pitched outside leg can save him now, you feel. It's definitely homing in on the stumps - and Hawk-Eye has it just pitching in line! De Kock's appeal fails, he's been dismissed for the first time in the series and Ben Stokes has made something happen for his team again
good length in the channel, de Villiers sticks out his back leg like a ballerina and leaves
slightly short on off stump, de Villiers tucks on down into the leg side
tossed up on off stump, pushed towards extra cover
bit of turn, nicely bowled, spins the legbreak past de Villiers' outside edge
flighted, comes forward to the pitch, opens the face and steers through cover point
pushed through on the stumps, goes back to defend
floated up, slow and loopy, comes forward to block
dragged down, short but quicker and it skids on to hit du Plessis on the knee as he tries to pull, heading down the leg side
length ball around fourth stump, precise forward defensive from ABd
pitched up and driven without timing to mid-off
straighter line, shuffles across and nurdles one out towards deep midwicket
skips out, Stokes digs the ball in, mistimed pull from high up the bat rolls through mid-on
off-stump line, steered square
length outside off, 141kph and de Villiers jumps across, plinks a drive into the covers
punched through the covers on the front foot, a misfield helps them to one
floated up around off stump, softly defended
tossed up on middle and leg, de Villiers calmly tucks a single back through mid-on
on the stumps, goes back and works one more through midwicket
looped up outside off stump, tapped down in front of square for another single
tighter on off, slow legbreak, defended coming forwards
full length, 140kph outside off stump, de Villiers whirls the arms through a drive out to deep cover
takes the pace off, poked into the covers half forward
another slower ball, slightly too straight this time and du Plessis can nurdle one away through square leg
length around off, busy-looking punch through the covers for a single
full and angling in, waits for it and clips through midwicket, cut off out towards deep midwicket
again takes the pace off, full and floaty out towards the tramlines, de Villiers swings hard but isn't quite seeing them at the moment and fails to connect
tossed up on middle and leg, goes down early to sweep but it hits the cue end and goes nowhere
punched down the ground to long-off
floated up outside off, comes forward and steers one through the covers
gives it some air, gets across and can't pick a gap this time
loopy legbreak on off stump, du Plessis leans into an inside-out drive, well placed between two boundary riders for a couple
on the stumps, nudged into the leg side for a single to finish the over
fullish outside off, comes forward and bunts into the covers
short ball, maybe taking the pace off again, du Plessis waits and angles the bat, slightly top-edgey but it runs safely down to third man
slightly short and de Villiers runs one more down to third man
pitched up and lashed through extra cover, nothing wrong with du Plessis' timing there... cracked to the fence for the first boundary since the 10th over
full again, slower ball, du Plessis waits and dabs it behind square
length ball, de Villiers happy to stroll in the park for now, pushed through the covers
tossed onto a good length, worked up to mid-on
dabbed into the leg-side, a measured single to midwicket
forward, a conventional leg-break, works with the spin into the covers
fuller length, drifting onto middle stump and defended down the ground
patted out to point, good picking of the gaps
on the pads, a long chase for Jordan from slip but the ball eases up inside the rope
tossed up on the off stump, worked into the leg-side, excellent placement and an easy second run
straighter line, nurdled into the leg side but square leg swoops to gather
beautiful strike. Improvisation from de Villiers who rolls his wrists into a reverse-dab and a slither of bat is all that is needed to beat third man
worked to mid-on
sliding down the leg side this time
a bit of a hack across the line and lots of excitement as Roy at short midwicket anticipated a straighter shot. Had he stayed put that might have been down his throat!
well bowled, du Plessis can't get bat on that one
patted to cover
a perfectly weighted push for two into the leg-side, the lack of pace on the shot ensured they had time to turn before deep midwicket reached it
tip and run as de Villiers milks the strike

pitches, grips, edged, gone! Du Plessis tried to angle his shot into the leg side, he was seduced by the drift but beaten by the spin as that one took a leading outside edge, for Jordan to tumble well and gather at slip!
forward in defence as Duminy beds in
full length, met in the blockhole, pushed to mid-on
jabbed to mid-on
forward once again, good flight and a bit of turn outside off
driven down to long-on
fully forward, picking the single in the covers, that's the hundred up
padded away from a leg-stump line. The ball balloons in the air but nowhere near the glove
on the pads, turning into the leg-side, busily bunted to midwicket
driven with hard hands and a bit of an open face. It looks initially like a bit of an edge, but de Villiers played for that, running through third man with a deliberate steer. Superb
punched into the covers
nurdled to short backward square, into position early on the sweep
tossed up on off stump, driven to mid-off
turning into the leg-side, worked out to deep square leg. Rashid is content to sacrifice the singles for now
fully forward, defended back up the pitch
standing firm in defence, climbs a bit after pitching
up on the toes, picking the gap at cover with a delicate steer
on the pads, flicked to short square
working with the spin, stepping across the crease and angling a nudge into the leg-side. It's uneventful accumulation for the moment
full face of the bat, pushed down to long-off
back and across, defended from deep in the crease, seemed to be looking for something more expansive at first
positive intent, a gallop down the track to work another single to midwicket
defended out to the leg-side
swept hard, but can't beat square leg
body behind the line, patted back to the bowler. That's a tidy over
solidly forward
round the wicket, turning down the leg-side
straighter line, lively at the crease to work the ball to midwicket
a pre-meditated reverse sweep but the ball eludes AB's contortions
straight line once again, it's restrictive and AB looks a touch frustrated
wicket-to-wicket, defended from back on the stumps
punched down to long-on, England's spinners whittling through the Boring Middle Overs (TM)
flicked out to square leg
forward and pushed to mid-off
clipped to midwicket, an instant call
slow spin from slightly back of a length, languidly steered out to deep cover
flicked firmly to the leg side
width and chopped down into the crease, and up over the head of slip. Tidy over once again
turns from the straight, worked with the spin to square leg
big stride forward and defended
a big appeal as Duminy slides back onto his stumps, but that was missing leg
tapped to cover and another urgent single
nudged round the corner
round the wicket, sharp spin from a full length, beats the edge and the stumps. Well bowled
tapped out to midwicket
worked to midwicket
strikes the pad
works with the spin, out to cover
pushed into the covers, another big stride
googly, well flighted and de Villiers settles for a push back down the pitch
patted into the covers once more
flicked round the corner and swiftly tidied up at short backward square
reverse sweep, AB's tricks are all coming out but he's not getting the placement as yet
forward and defended to mid-on
watchfully forward
there we go, that's de Villiers at his improvisatory best! A firmly struck reverse sweep, almost a pull by the time he made contact, deliberately over the short fielder and a welcome boundary
flapped off the hip from a static stance, French Cricket-style
ripper! Drifts in, grips and fizzes away. De Villiers is comprehensively beaten
forward, solid bat on ball
down the track, clipped firmly down to long-on
a flowing drive, but no timing
full length, spinning away, Duminy stands tall on the back foot to defend. The end of an excellent spell from Rashid. 10-0-43-1
patted down the ground, another jogged single
tip and run, a quick single into the cover, and AB is alert to the wayward shy, or rather a bit of lummuxish fielding. Two extra runs
blocked down the ground
what on earth, more bonus runs, in a near-identical fashion, as Willey has a shy, completely misses, and the man backing up can't get close!
well, that's rather ransacked Moeen's otherwise fine figures ...
good start, wicket to wicket stuff, full length, defended on the back foot
banged in short and Duminy flings his bat at that rather greedily, through the stroke far too soon and nearly splices his pull to short midwicket
a better strike, a flowing drive out to the cover sweeper
forward and defended to cover
a big swish of the bat, muscling a drive into the covers. But the sweeper is well positioned
fully forward, punched out to the deep, the left-hander's cover sweeper in business again
round the wicket, solid areas
big stride, good length, defended
looking for the quick single to cover but Ali's line and length are spot on
round the wicket again, settling into a fine groove in this over
very full, cramped for room to free the arms, tapped to the off side
attempted flick as Moeen goes straighter, but Duminy can't get bat on ball. A rare maiden, well bowled
a flowing drive out to the cover sweeper again, who is entitled to file for overtime
firm strike, the best of Duminy for several overs, but he doesn't get full value as short cover dives well to take the sting off the shot. The cover sweeper, him again, gallops round to tidy
short, and this one sticks on the pitch as Duminy pulls late and can't get the ball away properly, It ricochets down into the crease
wristily drilled out to the deep once more. Good urgent running brings a second as the throw comes in
opens the face to glide to third man, a touch more width this time
on the pads, flicked square and there is AB de Villiers' fifty. A very calm and threatening innings. He is now supremely set, and with 16 overs to come, who knows what he could compile from here...
forward, and worked round the corner, Sharp running even as short backward square gathers
round the wicket, bunted to short cover
straightens into Duminy who looks for a moment to have edged to slip, but that was straight off the pad. He's not enjoying the Moeen challenge
attempted sweep, down the leg side
defended into the gap for a welcome single
nudged off the pads, de Villiers has far fewer problems rotating the strike
driven down the ground to long on. Another very tidy over from Moeen
on the pads, half an appeal but always optimistic. Worked to midwicket
tight line and length, punched back to the bowler who leaps in his followthrough to gather
driven out to cover
tight line and length
over the wicket to the left-hander, who is cramped by the line and can't work the ball off his hip
clunked into the covers, Duminy keeps the strike, and that will be drinks
fired in flat on off stump, Duminy blocks square on the off side
tossed up outside off, reaches for the drive and Moeen scampers to his right to field
flighted, on the front foot, pressed to extra cover
tossed up and worked away through square leg off the back foot
AB throws it straight back to JP, punching one to long-on
pushed through on leg stump, hits the pads and rolls into the leg side as Duminy tries to play across the line
back of a length, angled down leg and flicked fine for one
short again, nudged off the hips, possibly a little pad involved and it loops wide of Buttler
short ball, de Villiers tries to clout Jordan over the leg side but only manages a bottom edge into his midriff
gets it away this time, although not where he was aiming... skipped out and heaved for his life, got a thick top edge wide of the keeper and down to third man
Jordan tries something different in response, rolls the fingers over one - down the leg side
on the pads and skimmed away to fine leg

short and Duminy cuts at it, thick edge but Buttler drops it! Jordan had already begun to celebrate, still no luck for him... Buttler was moving to his left, went for it one-handed and the ball clunked out
starts with a cutter, on the stumps and pulled to leg
skips out and slaps four through extra cover, flowing drive on the up and into a gap for a welcome boundary
on the pads, Duminy flicks at it and Buttler does well to dive and prevent the ball running away for four
full, angling in, wristy flick from de Villiers, into a gap between fine leg and deep square
pitched up in the slot and hammered through the covers, straight to the man on the fence
tucked off the body, there's a direct hit at the striker's end as the batsman scrambles... No drama
shortish and Sepp Blattered through mid-on, dancing out to flat-bat a pull past the man on the edge of the ring. Eat my goal
back in the crease, runs one to third man
this comes back in at ABdV, beats him past the inside edge as he tries to carve through the off side
full outside off, crunches a drive in front of deep extra cover for two
woof, that's a whisker from hitting leg stump! Full and straight from Jordan, tailing in again and de Villiers played around it, lucky not to get bowled
drops short, de Villiers locks on and tonks it into the crowd! Murderous swing to leg and the ball disappears for AB's first six of the innings. Time to bring out the glow sticks?
angled in from around the wicket, drops back and gets a bottom edge down by his toes
banged into the pitch, walloped through midwicket in front of the fielder
fired down the leg side, just a flick of the pad and it beats Buttler on its way through

full and dispatched high into the leg side... hang on, that's coming down with ice on it, and Jordan makes the catch! Brilliant work, running back to take a steepler over his shoulder, diving full length - never in doubt with that man. AB has been gunned down just as he looked to be getting going
stays back and steers one through the covers
back of a length and punched into the covers

pitched up and Duminy is hit on the pads, aiming a drive down the ground... and given! Looked a little leg side but SA used their review for de Kock's dismissal so Duminy will have to drag himself away. Yes, Hawk-Eye shows the ball missing leg stump, not a great decision but, in this case, the umpire's word is final
goes full the yorker again, punched down the ground for one off his first ball
pitched up outside off and spanked through the covers, Topley is slightly off with his length and Rossouw cashes the cheque in style
sliding down the leg side, Buttler does well to keep it to one
gets across and taps the ball down into the covers
pitched up and driven towards mid-on, Morgan makes an excellent diving stop and a direct hit would have been interesting, with Behardien attempting to get back
stroked through mid-on, another lovely piece of timing from Rossouw, beats Morgan this time and the man at long-off won't cut it off
slower ball, aiming for the tramlines... slightly out
on the stumps, played back to the bowler
shorter length, stays in the crease and turns neatly to leg with a roll of the wrists
fullish, Rossouw works it towards mid-on and times his run to perfection
on the stumps and dropped into the leg side one more
pitched up, 143kph outside off, mistimed drive to the left of mid-off and they pinch one more
goes full and wide, stays back and runs the ball through short third man
angled across the right-hander, who reaches for a dab behind point
goes full, tailing in on off stump, opens the face buts finds the man at point
full toss from Topley but he gets away with it, Rossouw had started to come forward and was cramped for room, played the ball on to his pads
sliding on to the pads, stays back and glances one through backward square leg
pitched up and driven through mid-on for a single down the ground

beats him on the inside, Buttler sprawls to take the catch low to his right... Topley appeals, Morgan likes it and England decide to review. Lots of high fives among the England players but Rossouw is calling for new gloves... Who's right? The ball was full and swinging in, Rossouw chopped down on it, possibly the sound was the bat hitting the ground. Can't see an obvious deflection and Ultra Edge is struggling to differentiate between the ball passing the bat and the bat hitting the ground. Think this will stay not out... But what do I know! Given, caught behind!
shortish, dropped down behind square on the off side, sends his partner back as the fielder hares in
full and straight, pushed down the ground through long-on
ho ho! Rabada doesn't bother taking a look, just steps out and plants his first ball over cover for a couple into the deep. So much to like about this fella
length ball around off stump, shuffles across and pokes at it, runs away off the inside edge
fullish on the stumps, Behardien ticks another down the ground
some shape away from the left-hander with the old ball, left alone outside off
pitched up, 135kph and driven into a gap in the covers
slips in the yorker, fractionally overpitched and Rabada sits back, flicks it on the full down to fine leg
angled across, Behardien drives and finds extra cover
full outside off, bunted into the ground and again extra cover cuts it off
pitched up, slightly wide and Behardien reaches to squeeze one out through cover point
late-swinging attempted yorker, but it's 131kph, more Alan Mullally than Wasim Akram and Rabada punches one down the ground
gets across outside off and taps one through the covers... England will be entirely happy with this approach, as the overs tick down
pitched up towards the blockhole, clipped through midwicket
Rabada has a hack, full and wide and he gets a thick outside edge down to third man on the bounce
length ball on the stumps, Behardien nurdles one more into the leg side
full on off stump, maybe a cutter, mistimed drive in the air towards long-on
on the toes, Behardien tries to get under it and manages to squirt the ball back past the diving Willey... It's like these two were watching Nasser Hussain's six-hitting lessons on Sky earlier
full and tailing away outside off, clunked through the covers for another single
that's a boundary, first one in a while! Gets the yorker wrong, just a touch on it from Rabada and he helps it on its way to fine leg

slower ball, Rabada swipes at it... top-edged to backward point! Smartly bowled, out the back of the hand and anticipating the attempt to go hard at the ball, looped up tamely to Morgan pedaling back to his right
pitched up on off stump, swatted into the covers
keeps firing it in full, tailing away from the right-hander, he stretches to steer on through cover point
fullish, 124kph on off stump, driven down the ground to long-off
on the stumps, Abbott tucks one away through square leg
goes very full and wide, Behardien can only slap a drive out to the cover sweeper
pitched up on the toes and worked back past the bowler to long-on
Behardien hits out, and does it well, to boot... backed away and launched a full ball over extra cover to the fence. Back atcha... And that's the 250 up
Stokes gets his yorker on target this time, chops down on it in front of leg stump, they pinch a single too
full of a length outside off, driven into the covers and Morgan is happy for Abbott to have one and stay on strike
pitched up and bunted back towards mid-on, room for a cheeky single
Behardien had gone back and across outside off, Topley follows him and lands a full ball on or around the tramlines... swing and a miss but it's not called, presumably because he'd moved there first
goes across again, this time digs out a drive through the off side
hammered out towards deep extra cover
Behardien pre-meditates to the off side, Topley tries a leg-stump slower ball but gets it slightly wrong
fired across the bows outside off, sliced down to third man
goes full and fast outside off, Abbott bungs it back down the ground for one more to long-off

inn2.comm: outside off, good line and length, no stroke yet as Roy assesses the conditions
left alone once again, taking the chance to have a few sighters outside off
solidly struck, firmly to mid-off
dropped! Though to be fair, Abbott did well to get a finger to a furiously drilled straight drive. Full, attacking and walloped hard back at the bowler
full length again, solid bat on ball, right behind the line
big fat outside edge, clean as a whistle through the newly vacant second slip! He's up and running, but plenty going on in that over ...
short, wide, sat up to be spanked, and Hales wastes no time, up on his toes and flogged fiercely to the point boundary
that's the spot from Rabada, a tighter line, a change-up in pace, and Hales' loose waft finds only dust outside off
onto the front foot, pushed firmly to cover, an instant call and though the shy hits the stumps Hales is safely home
through to the keeper, good wheels, KG
left alone with a flourish. Once again, de Villiers pulls out a slip to reinforce cover
solidly clocked back to the bowler. It's a battle of wills already in this innings
good line and length again from Abbott, aggressively tight
a fraction of width and Hales opens the face with a 'yeah, yeah, yeah' to scamper a single to third man
wristy work, that's a beautifully timed shot, capitalising on only a hint of width, but manipulating the gap behind point like a maestro
worked into the leg-side this time
clobbered down the ground, that was just a flumph through the line of the ball. Finesse go hang, but it was mightily effective. A big chase to no avail

nailed him! That is just the sweetest dismissal for a fast bowler, full length, fast, nipping off the seam and steam-rollering through the gate as Roy propped forward in an otherwise impeccable forward defence! The gap was there for a fraction of a second, and he dived straight through it like Indiana Jones rolling under a cave door
tight and threatening again
patted to cover
on the back foot, squeezed into the leg side
on the pads, nurdled out to deep midwicket, they hurtle back for the second, excellent running
up on the toes to defend
fast and full, pushed to cover again
lovely tight line, demanding respect, and receiving it
nibbling off the seam, and taking an inside-edge on an uncomfortable pokey defence. Perfect new-ball bowling
up on the toes and pushing into the covers
Hales is being forced to bide his time here, lovely line and length
defended with a flurry of limbs back down the wicket
a maiden over, and one that wouldn't have been out of place in a Test match. Tight again and pushed to mid-off
Rabada carries on where his new-ball partner left off
Root finds the gap, as he does often does, to rotate the strike
on the pads, flicked to backward square leg

big appeal and Root has been given out lbw! But he is going to review it. He thinks long and hard before doing so, the instinct is that that was sliding down leg as he played around his front pad, but all it needs is a flick on the stump ... and sure enough it is missing!
punched into the covers
tight line, full length, Rabada fields in his followthrough and attempts a back-flick onto Hales's stumps at the non-striker's end. Doesn't pull it off but nice thinking ...
Abbott continues, probing away on and around off stump
straight as a die once more
down the track to meet Abbott this time, but met with a straight face regardless of the intent
firmyl drilled off the front foot, into the covers, but no room to make any angles on the shot. Abbott bowling to his field perfectly
cracked out to backward point, du Plessis gathers

back of a length, whisked down to third man with a back-cut, good running once again, England have turned several ones into twos already in this innings, which could prove crucial in what promises to be a tricky chase
decent bat on ball, another single
shorter and sharper, Root is up on his toes to defend, digging the lifter out of his armpit
crunched into the covers, well protected in the ring. Rabada offered just a hint of width from back of a length but Root couldn't cash in
onto the front foot, driven hard into the covers again
tight line and length again, met with a one-handed defence, so tight to off stump that Root had to loosen his grip for the sake of remaining compact
beautiful bowling, defended into the leg side. What South Africa would have given for this pair leading the line at Bloemfontein on Wednesday
tight once again, respectful defence
punched into the gap at cover, a scream of encouragement as they hustle through for the precious single. Few and far between at the moment
tapped to point
threatening kick off a good length from the lanky Morkel
up on the toes and chopped to point
strays onto the leg stump and Root pounces, creating a half-volley with mischievous footwork and perfect timing. Lovely
full length, drilled into the covers but no chance to dictate terms for England's batsmen
that's the one for Hales! A plant of the front foot as Rabada over-pitches by a smidgeon. And through he flows with a arcing straight swing of the bat
nippier riposte from Rabada, Hales can't connect
full again and this one keeps low as well, Hales is lucky to get an under-edge as that could have splattered his middle stump as he hung back in the crease
poked out to point
bouncer, effective too. Root swings into a pull but the ball is gone
short, and Hales ducks
crunched into the covers, getting onto the front foot whenever possible
glided down to third man, good manipulation of the strike
good lift from a full length, up on the toes to defend
swished out to midwicket, just short enough to get on top of the shot
very full, a fraction of width, Hales runs his shot down to third man to keep the score ticking
on the leg stump, clipped to midwicket
miserable cricket all round! A stinking full toss, an even worse mow across the line, a massive top edge, and no-one gets close to it at mid-on!
Root returns the strike with less drama than his colleague
pounded through the covers. Another full toss and too much width too. Ick
forward and defended, better line and length
Tahir rescues the over. Only six runs from it, but could and should have been double-figures
Root bides his time
not particularly short at all, Root swings into a pull, Ricky Ponting style, but unlike Ponting, he doesn't nail it at all
dabbed out to backward square leg
up on the toes, defended into the crease
open faced, glided down to third man, well played, using the pace and fraction of width
inside-edge onto the pad, Root was aiming into the leg-side but couldn't time the stroke
driven into the covers, well fielded with a tumble
pounded hard out to deep midwicket. Solid timing but the sweeper tidies up
flicked up to long-on. Useful singles on offer
worked into the leg-side again, more strike rotation
on the pads, worked to leg, singles, singles everywhere
another single. Easy pickings ...

outside off, zipping through and is that an edge! Not out is the on-field verdict but it's going to review! That was zippier than Hales perhaps bargained for, but de Kock was absolutely adamant, reviewing before any discussion could be had... nothing on Snicko though ... curiouser and curiouser
back and across, and drilled hard to wide long-off where Duminy rushes round to field
on the toes from Hales again, who has a better measure of the pace now, and he even gets a bonus as the shy from point pings off his stumps and away to no-man's land
Root hands the strike back straightaway
walloped off the front foot, down to extra cover
good strike rotation
a thin tickle through the vacant cordon, looks like Root played for that shot, effective it was too
pushed into the leg-side
a firm bosh into the covers
flicked off the toes, out to square leg
Root finds the gap once more
opens the face to steer a drive through point and bring up a well-worked fifty-run stand.
wicket-to-wicket line, pushed out to point
on the back foot, meeting a straight ball with a straight bat. Long-off tidies up
beaten, that's a lovely line and length, probing on off stump and Root, anchored in the crease by the presence of de Kock up to the stumps, can't work it away
tight once again, defended into the gap
on the pads, flicked out to midwicket
onto the back foot, poked down the track. A tidy over, very little pace or width with which to make things happen
beaten outside off, a bit of a flat-footed waft
open face, eased down to third man, more good comfortable running
clunked out to deep square leg, flicked in the air and over the umpire
forward and defended down the ground
tight line, nibbling back into the batsman, flicked down to long-on
pushed onto the back foot, defended to point
length on off stump, defended without fuss coming forwards
straighter line and Root nurdles through the leg side... and they get back for the second
angled in with the arm, clipped to midwicket and de Villiers fields, hurls in a throw with Hales scrabbling to get back
full outside off, 122kph/75mph and pushed back down the ground to long-off
Hales presses forward and defends on off stump
wicket-to-wicket line, nudged off the pads for one more square on the leg side
length on middle and off, closes the face and turns to midwicket
bit of a woolly woof there, Hales hanging his bat out on the clothes line, past the edge
beaten on the inside, another wafty effort from Hales, trying to run one to third man
good length on off stump, comes forward to defend
shifts across on off stump early, Morkel fires it down the leg side... Flick and a miss, and a wide
length delivery on off stump, Hales happy to defend
full and straight, 144kph and sent skimming back down the ground, quickly off the bat as it arrived and for that reason mid-off has half a chance with a throw to the non-striker's end... but misses
round the wicket, floated up around off stump and straightening a touch, worked to leg
straighter, gets into line and clips to midwicket
floated up on the stumps, turns the wrists a bit further to squirt one through square
Root reverse the hands and gets the sweep away but straight to short third man
on the stumps and flicked for one to leg
delicately done by Hales, leans down and works a full ball round the corner, it will outrun short fine leg for a welcome boundary
drops back outside off and runs a shortish ball behind square
fuller length, comes forward and drives through the covers
on a good length in the channel, Root takes on the challenging run-and-slap-through-point... Misses
goes back and across, opens up the face and runs to third man
full on middle and leg, Hales leans forward and defends around his pad
gets into line and clips one more off his hips
tossed up outside off and driven through the covers
Root skips down the pitch, drills the ball to the left of mid-off and they take one more
on the stumps, nurdled through midwicket, past the valiant dive of du Plessis
goes back and flicks one more behind square
pushed across, Hales stays back and punches through point - more singles than an online dating site at the moment
tossed up on the stumps, punched back down the ground - England tick over to 100 in steady fashion
good length outside off, come forward and punches back past the bowler
getting a bit of shape back in, Hales tries to drive on the up and gets an inside edge
hello! Hales sees something he likes the look of a last and puts the moves on, opens up his shoulders and muscles a half-tracker away to wide long-on, one bounce for four
back to a good length, tapped into the covers for one
shortish and punched off the back foot, towards backward point where Faf gobbles it, Root sends Hales back as the throw comes in
good finish to the over, fast full-bunger at the toes, Root has to dig it out
wheels away, on middle and leg, clipped through midwicket
pushed across and steered through the covers
bit of width, Hales slaps one more out to the sweeper
tossed up and dribbled down the ground
on the stumps, Hales gets down to sweep, short fine leg takes the pace off but can't prevent one
big appeal for lbw, Duminy turning the ball back in... No deal, possibly a bit high and maybe not quite straightening enough from round the wicket
length outside off, Hales cuts down the angle and drives through the covers
on the stumps, worked through the leg side
back of a length, drops back and steers one more away through point
fired down the leg side... that won't work
short and at the body, Hales pulls one more through midwicket

on the move, tucked up, angled bat... and Root plays on! South Africa have their breakthrough and it's Abbott again! The Gopher of Economy has morphed into the Woodchuck of Penetration, he perhaps saw Root coming and dropped short, cramped him for space and he could only deflect the ball down on to his stumps
good length ball, 137kph on off stump, Morgan defends into the leg side
flighted, outside off, Hales punches towards cover
pushed through and he sweeps this time, finds the man at backward square leg
tossed up on the stumps, tucked into the leg side
flatter, outside off, goes back to cut but again finds a fielder
floated up, gets forward on off stump and whistles a drive past the dive of extra cover for one
stays over the wicket, legbreak straightening on off, Morgan taps it away
trundles in and puts the ball on a length outside off, fades past the inside edge as Hales wafts at it
gets the cut away, from right in front of the stumps, adroitly done by Hales, past short third man for a boundary
goes across and pokes the ball towards backward point
in the channel, reaching for a drive and it's carved in the air down to third man, where Morkel had just been sent... Might have been a catch if he was still on the edge of the ring
pitched up and driven in front of square, du Plessis cuts it off but they steal a single
pitched up and punched towards mid-off half forward
floated up on middle and leg, Morgan is down early to ramp a couple fine
flighted, in the slot around off stump, steps out and boshes a flat drive over long-off! Morgan announces himself with a trademark crunch down the ground
goes back and across to defend
floated up further, Morgan chops down on it in front of off stump
did he get something on that? I think so... Beaten by the googly but the touch took it past de Kock, a fiendishly difficult chance
tossed up on off stump, pushed into the covers
slightly short and wide and Morgan chops to point, not taken cleanly
back of a length around off stump, Hales opens the face and runs one to third man
comes forward and reaches for the drive, poked into the covers
Morgan skips out early, looking for the swipe over midwicket, has to check the shot as Rabada digs it in
back of a length, angled across and pulled from outside off stump through square leg
full outside off, 136kph and Hales throws the hands through a drive, thick inside edge but past leg stump for four!
flat delivery outside off, Morgan taps it down into the ground and it runs through slip for one
on the stumps, turned through backward square leg
shortish, outside off, cuts straight to backward point
angled across the left-hander, this time Morgan gets it through the infield

down the leg side, de Kock takes it and effects the stumping... Hales was overbalanced and falling forward, so we're going to see what the third umpire thinks, even though it was a wide. The batsman gives a thumbs up to his captain, thinking he was okay, and the replays agree, his back foot didn't leave the ground
comes forward and punches one down the ground
very full, sneaks through to hit the pads, deflects through gully... missing leg stump, I think
fullish, angled across, Morgan works it into a gap on the leg side
pitched up on the stumps, clipped back down the ground
Morgan waltzes down the pitch, hit on the pads as he swings across the line, the ball loops behind backward point... Might have been a cutter, think it pitched outside leg
this is definitely on the wobbly side, split-finger release, down the leg side
back of a length, bit of width and it's slapped through point
stays back and drills one more down the ground
tight lines, Morgan tries to heave to leg and is struck on the pads, the ball doesn't  go anywhere... probably missing off stump, despite de Kock's enthusiastic enquiry
drifts a little too far across and Morgan makes room the Kapow! a drive through the covers for four
takes the pace off, pushed down the ground
on the stumps, flicked through backward square leg
drops short and Morgan smacks it over deep midwicket, no messing about. Dismissively done, despite the lack of pace in the pitch, and that brings England's requirement down to exactly 100
on the stumps, Hales eases a single down the ground
pushed across, possibly the googly, Morgan sits back and dabs the ball to short third man, Morkel does well to grab it on the run, taking a chunk out of the outfield with his knee in the process
drags it down, Hales swivels to swat one more out to deep midwicket
flighted, on the stumps, swept behind square, Rabada has to run along the rope and they hustle two
presses forward to defend on off
googly, spinning sharply as Morgan aims a slog-sweep, into the gloves
on the pads, flicked fine
tight line, wicket to wicket, defended back down the track

a massive mow as Morgan is fractionally deceived by a slower ball, Morkel rolls his fingers down the side of the ball, de Villiers steadies himself at deep midwicket, and takes a vital breakthrough catch!
A lot on Hales' shoulders as Morkel keeps it tight
shorter, and pulled out to deep midwicket
outside off, swinging away, no stroke offered
opens the face to steer a drive to point
dabbed to backward point, probing the gaps
swept firmly, good connection as Hales drops to one knee to pick out deep midwicket, all along the ground

big appeal, Tahir is doing the full pogo, and that looked utterly plumb! It's given as leg byes as Stokes sweeps so no bat involved according to the umpire, but de Kock has already used up South Africa's review
tight line, defended
googly, Stokes lines up a reverse sweep, misses out and this time the finger goes up! Stokes uses his review ... he's a long way across, but has that pitched in line? Indeed, it was outside leg!
outside off, bounding through to the keeper
dabbed down to third man
shoulders arms and ushers the ball through

bowled him! Stokes hasn't looked comfortable at all in this innings, the slower deck working against him perhaps. Morkel angles one across the left-hander, cramping him for room outside off, and the ball doesn't get up much, cannons off the inside edge and into the stumps!
outside off, poked away
big appeal but outside the line as Buttler advances in a bid to clip to leg, his bat makes no contact but the pads do the trick. Important breakthrough in that over though ...
manipulates the strike to get off the mark
eased out into the deep, Hales picks off another pair of vital runs
big solid deliberate forward defence. Hales doesn't want to give this away now
whisked into the off side. Four off the over ... it'll do for now for England
stabbed into the leg side, a quick scampered single

on the back foot, a loose half-tracker from round the wicket. All the time and space in the world to pick the gap and flog the boundary. Hales chooses to go through the covers, and to excellent effect, beating the sweeper with power and placement
on the legs, worked square
Buttler pick-pockets another single into the covers
flicked off the hip to return the strike
pulled firmly in front of square, good running to keep up the pressure, and that's an important over, 10 coming off it as South Africa's fifth-bowler weakness is exposed again
short and skidding on, punched to mid-on
dabbed down the ground, off the back foot
easy accumulation from Buttler, no fireworks required
Hales moves to within three of a very fine hundred ...
pre-meditated sweep, another single
a bit chancy from Hales, who is early on the stroke and nearly chips a leading edge to cover. Steady now ...
clipped to square leg
eased down the ground to move to 98 ...
poked into the leg-side, they rotate the strike again
one more single, strolled down to long-on...
on the back foot, punched to cover. No way through there
on the pads, turned to square leg
Hales, on 99, bides his time ...

short, pulled, gloved ... on my Lord, what has Hales done?! It took an eternity for the finger to go up but his guilty look probably pulled his own trigger! A lobbed chance to de Kock as Hales grabbed at his chance for three figures, and well, that non-jinxy statement has had its non-intended non-effect!
on the pads, worked out to square leg
neatly done, but that was too full and too leg-sided from Abbott, who was looking for the yorker and gave Buttler a freebie on the toes instead
a hint of reverse swing from Abbott, good stop in the covers by Amla
defended into the covers
tapped to short cover, and yikes, that's a jittery attempt at a run! They make it home in the end but Moeen was rather eager to let his team-mate take the lead in this over
tonked. That's the way to do it. No point in standing on ceremony. Just bosh it, through backward square with a languid pull
out through backward point this time, good gap filching.
fuller length, pushed back down the ground
that's the spot, full and fuller, just outside off and angling across the left-hander. Nothing doing there except respectful defence
back of a length, and that's a very tidy finish to the over. Defended down into the crease, only two runs from the last four balls of the over. Shame about the second-ball four, but what can you do?
dabbed out to cover
poked back down the pitch, Abbott gathers in his followthrough
short, pulled through midwicket, a measured placement of a pull rather than a full-blooded mow
edged, but the keeper can't intercept! Nothing you can do as a bowler about that, a perfect ball, climbing at the edge, but without a slip in place what can you do?
slower ball, and that's a fine riposte, bunted through midwicket, and picks the gap nicely. Too short at that pace
crunched through backward square, and that is surely the game. A volley of runs, 12 in three balls, 16 off the over, and England's equation looks serene once again
another single, England easing along now
driven off the back foot, but can't pick the gap
full and straight, Rabada doing all he can to keep South Africa in the hunt
dead-batted to mid-off, and a sharp call allows them to scamper home before the shy comes in
on the pads, full again, worked into the leg side
very full once again, Buttler gets in a tangle as he attempts to work the ball away. Good tight work
chipped in the air ... Berhardien at long-off galloped across but it is dropped! Think Jordan's catch but much easier ...
Ali escapes the strike, as well he might
big stride, head over the ball, clears the front leg, battered into the stands. Fetch!
mowed over midwicket! Buttler can't be bothered to nudge and nurdle England to victory, he's got a long handle and he intends to use it!
flogged! Monstrous cross-batted assault, down on one knee, not a ring in sight though as Tahir is jilted into the stands, back over his head!
a rare dot-ball, but too little too late, that is a massive 21-run over
Moeen's turn to have a mow! A typical range-hitting stand-and-deliver blow, straight back whence it came. One bounce and into the rope
smashed through midwicket, game over!
